Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X15-0YK1-JBG3-62TT-00000-00Taliban, Brexit, Juul: Your Monday Evening Briefing2019-09-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:28:47ZLexisNexisBRIEFINGTaliban, Brexit, Juul: Your Monday Evening BriefingVictoria Shannon and Hiroko Masuike

Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

(Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

Good evening. Here’s the latest.

1. President Trump said peace talks with the Taliban were “dead as far as I’m concerned.”

The remarks may not be his last word, given his campaign promises to withdraw U.S. troops from Afghanistan.

The death of an American soldier in a car bombing last week was the reason Mr. Trump cited for abruptly ending the talks, but some Afghans were skeptical that one U.S. fatality could have upended the process when the deaths of thousands of Afghans had not.

Our reconstruction shows that Mr. Trump’s cancellation of his plan to bring the Taliban to Camp David was more nuanced — and as off the cuff as the idea itself.

Taliban violence continued unabated on Monday, with more civilian deaths, while the end of negotiations appeared to open the way for a presidential election in Afghanistan on Sept. 28.

2. It’s official: No no-deal Brexit — for now.

A measure requiring Britain to seek another extension from the European Union if there is no withdrawal agreement by Oct. 19 became law, dealing Prime Minister Boris Johnson a crushing blow.

Parliament (and protests) are going deep into the British night. The lawmakers are preparing to vote on whether to hold a snap general election, with Mr. Johnson likely to be rebuffed again. Then they adjourn until Oct. 14. Our live updates are here.

In addition, John Bercow, the speaker of the House of Commons who has made enemies in the Conservative Party, said he would step down by Oct. 31.

3. Juul misled smokers about safety, the F.D.A. said.

The dominant e-cigarette company violated federal regulations by selling its vaping products as a safe alternative to traditional tobacco cigarettes without approval, the agency said.

The warning came amid a public health crisis. More than 400 cases of vaping-related lung illnesses have been reported, and the ailments may be tied to five deaths.

Public health investigators have yet to determine a specific cause, but have cited the use of vaping products from a number of companies as possible suspects.

4. The tempest over the hurricane forecast keeps growing.

The secretary of commerce, Wilbur Ross, threatened to fire top employees at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration last week after its Birmingham office contradicted President Trump’s claim that Hurricane Dorian might hit Alabama, according to our sources.

That threat led to NOAA’s unusual disavowal of the Birmingham office’s statement.

On Monday, NOAA’s acting chief scientist sent an email to staff members that he was looking into “potential violations” in the agency’s decision to back Mr. Trump. He called the disavowal “a danger to public health and safety.”

5. Bernie Sanders has a long history with “Medicare for all.”

The Vermont senator has staked his presidential campaign on transforming American health care. His mother’s illness and a trip he made to study the Canadian system help explain why. Above, Mr. Sanders in 1988.

His dogmatic approach to health care has helped set the agenda among Democrats, and the issue will most likely be prominent once again as the candidates debate. The third debate is on Thursday in Houston.

We also look at how Senator Elizabeth Warren wooed wealthy donors for years, stockpiling money from fund-raisers, and has used $10.4 million from her 2018 Senate race to underwrite her presidential bid.

6. Another British mess: the airline strike.

Pilots striking on Monday for more pay from British Airways will be off the job again on Tuesday, resulting in some 1,700 flight cancellations and 195,000 passengers being rescheduled or getting refunds. Above, Heathrow’s nearly deserted Terminal 5.

They plan another strike for Sept. 27.Here’s what travelers need to know.

British Airlines said it had contacted customers two weeks ago to offer a choice of full refunds or alternative flights, even on different airlines. It was not exactly a seamless process.

7. Help wanted. A lot of help.

Amazon says it has 30,000 jobs open in the U.S., the most it’s ever had. The openings reflect a company growing in many directions and a national unemployment rate near a 50-year low.

The posts don’t even include hourly, seasonal positions like warehouse workers. In fact, more than half the jobs are tech-oriented. The company is holding hiring fairs next week in Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Nashville, Seattle and Arlington, Va.

At the same time, Amazon is a target of government scrutiny over whether it improperly favors its own products and services. We have a breakdown of the various Big Tech investigations. A new one today, from state attorneys general, focuses on   the market power of Facebook and Google.

8. It’s a big week for new books.

The actor George Takei gives a detailed, wrenching account of what happened to thousands of Japanese-Americans — including himself, at age 5 — in the wake of Pearl Harbor in his new graphic memoir, “They Called Us Enemy.”

Other highly anticipated books out this week include “The Institute,” Stephen King’s latest, and   “Gender and Our Brains” by Gina Rippon on the myths of the male and female minds.

See our latest reviews here.

9. Some of the N.F.L.’s preseason expectations are already history.

Baltimore’s Lamar Jackson, above, was assumed to be a runner, but he emerged as a productive passer. And the Cleveland Browns, forecast as a contender, proved hapless.

But Kansas City is still a bona fide Super Bowl candidate, and so are the Los Angeles Rams. See the rest of our N.F.L. reporter’s assessment of Week One.

The Browns weren’t the only ones to leave crucial points on the table. Colts and Jets kickers had wobbly starts, too.

But our favorite sports-related story today is about a Florida kid’s homemade T-shirt.

10. Parsing the picks in the fantasy leagues.

Data from thousands of fantasy football drafts provided by ESPN shows that the running back Saquon Barkley of the Giants was the top pick.

There was also strong preseason agreement on Christian McCaffrey of the Panthers, Alvin Kamara of the Saints and Ezekiel Elliott of the Cowboys.

But quarterback choices were all over the map. Compare your picks.

Have an interference-free evening.

Your Evening Briefing is posted at 6 p.m. Eastern.

And don’t miss Your Morning Briefing. Sign up here to get it by email in the Australian, Asian, European or American morning.

Want to catch up on past briefings? You can browse them here.

What did you like? What do you want to see here? Let us know at briefing@nytimes.com.
